ygData.subject: Re: [EQ_women] Crossdressing in Eq...
ygData.msgSnippet: ... From: Skinner, Rosalind A CSC To: EQ_women@egroups.com ; EQ_women@egroups.com Sent: Tuesday, December 12, 2000 10:54 AM Subject: RE: [EQ_women]
ygData.messageBody:
----- Original Message -----
From: Skinner, Rosalind A CSC
To: EQ_women@egroups.com ; EQ_women@egroups.com
Sent: Tuesday, December 12, 2000 10:54 AM
Subject: RE: [EQ_women] Crossdressing in Eq...

That theory falls in line with a lot of stereotyping. Why would you afford a
female character more advantage than a male? Personally, I don't care WHAT
sex the character is, it's whether or not they can play the game.
 
Actually, the "advantage" theory comes from other men noticing that their peers will give stuff to and help female types more readily than they will other male types.  And this is something I've seen time and time again, to be quite frank.  My partner (in and out of games) grumbles about it alot; I always got offered stuff and if I asked for help, I'm more likely to receive it if the other person thinks I'm female.  I used to believe that alot of that has to do with personality--I'm very friendly--but my guy friends don't think so. <wry grin>  SO, this doesn't have anything to do with what *we* think! <laughing> 


Another thing, people always assume that you are male. Whenever I'm in wolf
form, people always say "Ask Soril, he's got food." Or "I'm waiting for him
to get back"...I always laugh. My name to me, doesn't even SEEM male.
 
Well, I had played Asheron's Call briefly, before school started back up for me, and I played a female character that was very taciturn and didn't speak much (although she wasn't rude or anything; just a quiet type).  I had people refer to me as a "he" and "him", even though my graphic was a female!  It's funny.  When Horizons is finally released (and Neverwinter Nights too), I plan to have at least one male character and see how people respond to him.  I played one in D&D way back when, and it's just not the same when everyone can see you're a girl.  I thought I did a very credible job with Dirk, too.  Like I said, we'll see!


Regardless, I could care less, I just want to play with people who can play
the game.

Soril
You said it!  I still keep in touch with some of the people I met in EQ and of course, I lurk around in here as well. <grins at Christina>  I've been playing D&D lately and have rediscovered the fun I had when I was a kid and a teenager, and I tell all the ex-UO and EQ people I know to check it out again.  My partner is chomping at the bit, waiting for the next MMORPG, but between school and our weekly gaming group, I am content to sit back in my corner by the fire and listen to the rest of the room share their tales.

Christina, when did you depart for greener pastures???
 
 
Aelwesara C├╗thalion, Ranger of Povar and worlds to come
Suzanne Johnson
